title: Glycosyltransferases promote development and prevent promiscuous cell

The evolution of multicellular eukaryotes from their single-celled ancestors was a 42 major transition in evolutionary history and allowed for the subsequent origin and 43 diversification of complex macroscopic life (Leigh et al., 1995) . However, despite the 44 centrality of multicellularity to the origin and diversification of animals, little is known 45 about the genetic and developmental mechanisms that precipitated the transition to 46 multicellularity in the animal stem lineage. To test whether a bulk segregant approach would work in S. rosetta, we first 158 analyzed a cross between the previously mapped Rosetteless mutant and the Mapping 159

Mapping Strain´Rosetteless cross (Levin et al., 2014) , grew clonal cultures from each, 161 pooled the resulting cultures, extracted their genomic DNA, and sequenced the pooled 162 mutant genomes to an average coverage of 187X. Against a background of sequence 163 variants that did not segregate perfectly with the Rosetteless phenotype, five unlinked 164 single nucleotide variants (SNVs) and insertions/deletions (INDELs) were found to 165 perfectly segregate with the phenotype (Table S2 ). Four of these detected sequence 166 variants likely had spurious correlations with the phenotype resulting from relatively low 167 sequencing coverage at those variants (>0.25X coverage of the entire genome) ( Table  168 S2). In contrast, the remaining SNV was detected in a well-assembled portion of the 169 genome at a sequencing depth approaching the average coverage of the entire 170 genome. The perfectly segregating SNV, at position 427,804 on supercontig 8, was 171 identical to the causative mutation identified in Levin et al., 2014 (Table S2) . Thus, a 172 method based on pooling F1 haploid mutants, identifying sequence variants that 173 perfectly segregated with the phenotype, and masking those SNVs/INDELs that were 174 detected with >0.25X coverage of the total genome was effective for correctly 175 pinpointing the causal mutation for Rosetteless (Figure 2-figure supplement 1 Jumble that segregated perfectly with both the clumping and rosette defects.
